Let's talk about what's happening in Zimbabwe now on Monday Zimbabwe held their first presidential election
Since Robert Mugabe was ousted from power November of last year and a bring everyone up to speed a quick history of Zimbabwe and Mugabe
Robert Mugabe has held on to power in Zimbabwe for nearly 40 years ever since he and his political party 'Zanu PF' helped Zimbabwe achieve
Independence from the UK and since the late 90s elections in the country have been widely considered a sham and international observers
Weren't even allowed to watch them but also due to economic practices and a corrupt government Zimbabwe economy stagnated and inflation soared
I mean we're talking to the point where they were printing 100 trillion Zimbabwe dollar bills

even Mugabe's own party was fed up and he was voted out of office since and Zanu PF appointed emerson and gag wa-hoo

But they appointed him president until Monday's election
Monday's election was both presidential and parliamentary Zanu-PF had EM running to be president in their biggest rival was Nelson
Cha Misa and Nelson was from the MDC alliance and in massive international news for the first time in nearly two decades
International observers were allowed to come and actually watch the election process and regardless of whoever was going to win many
Zimbabweans were just hopeful for some meaningful change in the country and in the lead-up to the election
We saw supporters of e/m
hold a massive rally last Saturday at National Stadium in the capital general feelings been that e/m would win and he would win by a

Zimbabwe to foreign investors and attempt to turn around the economy and on the other side you have his main opponent
Chammiya, who is very popular with young voters and in Zimbabwe that's incredibly meaningful because that's more than 40% of registered voters

What we ended up seeing is that 70% of the 5 million registered voters
Turned up to vote atmosphere in general was described as peaceful
There were rallies for both sides and then on Tuesday the MDC Alliance announced that Nelson chammiya had won the presidential election
despite the fact that the Zimbabwe

which is notable cuz those are the votes you need to change the

so ZEC's announcement on Wednesday set off protests across the country including
Massive ones in the capital supporters of Jamia in general furious over the ZEC's delay in announcing a presidential winner as well as the results
Of the parliamentary vote many claiming that ZEC is corrupt and controlled by zanu-pf a claim
they have long had and why they wanted international observers at the election and on that note foreign observers have said they want ZEC to

supporters shouting we support Nelson, chammiya

We have won the popular vote you voted for change in this past election
We have won this one together

But unfortunately things escalated quickly and from here
The timeline is very confusing and there are accusations being thrown by both sides
but here's what we know for sure riot police were called to deal with the protesters some of which that had turned somewhat violent or
At the very least destructive tearing down Zanu PF signs and billboards of e/m's face
There was other minor property damage
Riot police began using tear gas and water cannons on the protesters who in turn refused to disperse from there
The military was called for as of right now an unknown reason and the violence ramped up quickly
There's videos of people being beaten by the soldiers and police tear gas being shot live ammunition being shot into crowd
There were reliable reports that six and possibly more have been killed and an unknown amount injured armored military vehicles have also been videoed cruising through
The Capitol trying to keep the peace and squash the riots
Of course during all this MDC reporters are adamant that the vote was being stolen from them one supporters saying I'm feeling angry at what?
CEC and zanu-pf are do what air conniving together to steal our votes. We are here to defend our vote

especially the use of soldiers on civilians
They are currently defending themselves by claiming that MDC alliance is the one to be blamed. e/m saying in a video statement

for this disturbance of national peace which was meant disrupt the Electoral process"

"from these acts of political violence which they have aided and abetted."
Which an MDC alliance spokesman responded

"we condemn in the strongest sense he action that was taken today"
